compound-interest.title: Compound Interest
compound-interest.description: Estimate growth of an investment with recurring contributions and compounding.
compound-interest.explainer: This calculator shows how your money grows through compound interest over time. Conservative estimates: 3-4% (bonds/savings), moderate: 6-7% (diversified portfolio), aggressive: 8-10% (stocks). Always consider inflation and taxes.

guides.title: How to Use the Compound Interest Calculator
guides.description: Master the power of compound growth with this step-by-step guide to the calculator features.

guides.title: Monthly vs Annual Compounding: What's the Difference?
guides.description: Understand how compounding frequency affects your returns and which option to choose.

guides.title: Setting Realistic Return Expectations
guides.description: Historical market returns: US stocks (10%), bonds (5%), inflation (3%). Use conservative estimates for planning.

debt-payoff.title: Debt Payoff Planner
debt-payoff.description: Build a month‑by‑month plan using snowball or avalanche and optional extra payments.
debt-payoff.explainer: Two proven debt payoff strategies: Snowball (smallest balance first) builds motivation, Avalanche (highest rate first) saves more money. Choose based on your personality and situation.

guides.title: How to Use the Debt Payoff Planner
guides.description: Step-by-step guide to plan your debt freedom journey with snowball vs avalanche strategies.

guides.title: Snowball vs Avalanche: Which Strategy Wins?
guides.description: Compare the psychological benefits of snowball method vs the mathematical efficiency of avalanche.

guides.title: Common Debt Payoff Mistakes to Avoid
guides.description: Avoid these pitfalls that keep people in debt longer than necessary.

emergency-fund.title: Emergency Fund Planner
emergency-fund.description: Calculate your ideal emergency fund target and timeline based on monthly expenses and risk tolerance.
emergency-fund.explainer: Emergency fund basics: 3 months for stable jobs, 6 months for variable income, 9+ months for single-income families. Start with $1,000, then build to 1 month, then your full target.

guides.title: Emergency Fund Size Guide
guides.description: 3 months: stable job, dual income. 6 months: commission/variable income. 9+ months: single income, self-employed, or unstable industry.

guides.title: Emergency Fund vs Sinking Funds Explained
guides.description: Learn the difference between emergency funds and targeted sinking funds for planned expenses.

guides.title: Where to Keep Your Emergency Fund
guides.description: Best accounts for emergency funds: high-yield savings, money market, or short-term CDs.

savings-rate.title: Savings Rate & FI Date
savings-rate.description: Calculate your savings rate and estimate when you can achieve financial independence.
savings-rate.explainer: Financial Independence = having 25x your annual expenses invested (4% rule). Higher savings rates dramatically reduce time to FI: 10% savings = 51 years, 25% = 32 years, 50% = 17 years.

guides.title: What's a Safe Withdrawal Rate?
guides.description: Understand the 4% rule and how different withdrawal rates affect your FI timeline.

guides.title: 5% vs 7% Return Scenarios
guides.description: Compare conservative vs optimistic return assumptions and their impact on your FI date.

guides.title: How to Increase Your Savings Rate
guides.description: Practical strategies to boost your savings rate and accelerate your path to FI.

goal-timeline.title: Goal Timeline Planner
goal-timeline.description: Plan when you'll reach your savings goal with regular contributions and optional step-ups.
goal-timeline.explainer: This calculator shows how long it will take to reach your savings goal and breaks down the contributions vs growth. You can model step-up scenarios where you increase your savings over time.

guides.title: Lump Sum vs Monthly Saving
guides.description: Compare the effectiveness of making a large initial investment vs consistent monthly contributions.

guides.title: Step-Up Savings Plans
guides.description: How gradually increasing your contributions can dramatically shorten your timeline to goals.

guides.title: Setting Realistic Timeline Goals
guides.description: How to balance aggressive savings goals with sustainable lifestyle choices.

refinance-breakeven.title: Refinance Break-Even
refinance-breakeven.description: Calculate when refinancing pays off by comparing closing costs to monthly savings.
refinance-breakeven.explainer: This calculator shows how long it takes to break even on refinancing costs and your total interest savings over the loan term. Consider refinancing when you'll stay in the loan longer than the break-even period.

guides.title: When NOT to Refinance
guides.description: Learn the scenarios where refinancing might not make financial sense despite lower rates.

guides.title: Rate Drop vs Fees Tradeoffs
guides.description: How to weigh interest rate savings against upfront refinancing costs.

guides.title: Refinancing Timeline Guide
guides.description: Step-by-step process and timeline for refinancing your mortgage or loan.

budget-splitter.title: 50/30/20 Budget Splitter
budget-splitter.description: Split your take-home pay using the popular 50/30/20 rule or create custom budget percentages.
budget-splitter.explainer: Popular budget rules: 50/30/20 (needs/wants/savings), 70/20/10 (expenses/savings/fun), or 80/20 (expenses/savings). Adjust percentages based on your debt level, income, and goals.

guides.title: Which Budget Rule is Right for You?
guides.description: 50/30/20: balanced approach. 70/20/10: aggressive savings. 80/20: debt payoff mode. Adjust based on your phase of life.

guides.title: How to Adjust for Irregular Income
guides.description: Budgeting strategies for freelancers, contractors, and variable income earners.

guides.title: Needs vs Wants: The Reality Check
guides.description: Needs: housing, utilities, groceries, minimum debt payments, insurance. Wants: dining out, entertainment, upgrades. Gray areas require honest assessment.

extra-payment.title: Extra Payment Impact
extra-payment.description: See how extra payments can dramatically reduce your loan term and interest costs.
extra-payment.explainer: Extra payments go directly to principal, reducing interest dramatically. Rule of thumb: if loan rate > expected investment return, pay extra. Otherwise, invest the difference. Early payments have bigger impact.

guides.title: Best Time to Add Extra Payments
guides.description: When in your loan term extra payments have the biggest impact on interest savings.

guides.title: One-Time vs Recurring Extra Payments
guides.description: Compare the benefits of lump sum payments vs consistent monthly extra payments.

guides.title: Extra Payments vs Investing
guides.description: When to pay down debt vs invest the extra money in the market.

credit-card-minimum.title: Credit Card Minimum Cost
credit-card-minimum.description: See the true cost of paying only minimum payments on credit card debt.
credit-card-minimum.explainer: Minimum payments are designed to maximize bank profits, not help you. Typical minimums: 2-3% of balance or $25 minimum. Paying minimums on $5,000 at 19.99% takes 18+ years and costs $7,000+ in interest.

guides.title: Why Minimums are Dangerous
guides.description: How credit card companies design minimum payments to maximize their profits.

guides.title: Set Your Own Floor Payment
guides.description: Strategies for setting higher baseline payments to escape the minimum payment trap.

guides.title: Minimum Payment Alternatives
guides.description: Better payment strategies: avalanche, snowball, and percentage-based approaches.

debt-to-income.title: Debt-to-Income Ratio
debt-to-income.description: Calculate your debt-to-income ratio to understand your financial health and borrowing capacity.
debt-to-income.explainer: DTI is a key metric lenders use. Total DTI includes all monthly debt payments ÷ gross monthly income. Good: <36%, Acceptable: 36-41%, High risk: >41%. Housing alone should be <28%.

guides.title: Understanding DTI Ratios
guides.description: How lenders use debt-to-income ratios and what different levels mean for your financial health.

guides.title: Improving Your DTI Ratio
guides.description: Strategies to reduce debt payments and increase income to improve your borrowing power.

guides.title: DTI for Different Loan Types
guides.description: DTI requirements vary: conventional mortgages (43%), FHA (57%), auto loans (10-15%), credit cards (varies).
